The definition of Odd is here:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Ring/Parity.html#Odd

Copied here for convenience:

def Odd {α : Type u_2} [Semiring α] (a : α) :
Prop
An element a of a semiring is odd if there exists k such a = 2*k + 1.

Equations
Odd a = ∃ (k : α), a = 2 * k + 1

I'm a beginner so I can't see how or why this definition doesn't apply to rationals, reals, or even complex numbers.

The definition seems to suggest that k=0.5 leads to a=2*k + 1 = 1 + 1 = 2 is Odd.

k doesn't seem to be defined as only ℕ or ℤ.

What have I missed?

The definition does apply - but every real number is indeed Odd so the notion is not very interesting in that case:

import Mathlib

example : Odd (2 : ℝ) := by
  use 0.5
  norm_num

I find this upsetting :(

(I'm half joking)

So I have to ask - why? Surely it is easy enough to constrain the definition to ℕ or ℤ ?
So, 2 : ℝ is Odd but 2 : ℤ is not. A bit like 2 : ℝ is inversible but 2 : ℤ is not.

rzeta0 said:

So I have to ask - why? Surely it is easy enough to constrain the definition to ℕ or ℤ ?

Then you couldn't talk about elements of ZMod 12 being even or odd
ZMod 12 ... ok so we're going beyond my knowledge. I'll assume there is a good reason :)
I think your implied question of "why is Odd (2 : Real) not a type error" is a reasonable one
But limiting it to only natural numbers and integers would not be a good design either.
rzeta0 has marked this topic as resolved.
